title: Autism And Intelligence: Much More Than You Wanted To Know
summary:
Key ideas:
- Studies have found a genetic correlation between educational attainment and autism risk, as well as cognitive ability and IQ.
- Relatives of autistic people usually have many of the genes for autism, but not be autistic themselves, and they tend to be unusually smart and more inclined to technical subjects.
- Autism is caused by a combination of familial genes, rare de novo mutations, and non-genetic factors.
- Autism is associated with low IQ, and even cases of autism caused entirely or mostly by normal genetics are associated with unusually low IQ.
- There may be a tower-versus-foundation model where higher intelligence outstrips the ability of some mysterious foundation to support it, resulting in autism.

Key learnings:
- Genes that contribute to autism risk also contribute to high IQ, but autistic people generally have lower intelligence than neurotypical controls.
- The existence of a well-defined subset of low IQ people whose relatives have higher-than-predicted IQs is a surprising finding that cuts through the measurement difficulties and suggests that this is a real phenomenon.
- Every autism case is caused by some combination of familial genes, rare de novo mutations, and non-genetic factors.
- A tower-versus-foundation model suggests that autism may be caused by an imbalance between P (as the tower) and V + R (as the foundation).

Key questions:
- What is going on with the correlation between autism and IQ?
- Why do relatives of autistic patients have higher IQs and autistic patients themselves have much lower ones?
- What are the causes of autism, and how do they affect intelligence?
- How can the tower-versus-foundation model explain the autism-IQ paradox?
- What is the nature of the mysterious foundation in the tower-versus-foundation model?
